initial_story:
A US Army soldier stationed in South Korea has been detained in Russia, the US military says.

The Russian foreign ministry said the charges were not related to "politics or espionage", but to a "purely domestic crime".

The 34-year-old was not on official travel when he was held on 2 May in the city of Vladivostok, in Russia's Far East.

Sgt Black had been in the process of changing duty stations from South Korea to Fort Cavazos in the US state of Texas, according to a statement from the US Army.

But instead of returning to the US, he travelled through China to Vladivostok for personal reasons, US Army spokeswoman Cynthia Smith said in a statement.

According to Russian media, he was visiting a woman with whom he had a romantic relationship.

The soldier's mother, Melody Jones, confirmed to CBS that he was in Russia visiting his girlfriend.

"Please do not torture him [or] hurt him," Melody Jones said when asked about her message to the Russians.

Sgt Black enlisted as an infantryman in 2008 and was deployed to Iraq in 2009 and Afghanistan in 2013. He was most recently assigned to the Eighth Army, US Forces Korea at Camp Humphreys in South Korea.

He did not request official clearance and the defence department did not authorise his travel to China or Russia, the US Army said. There is no evidence he intended to remain in Russia.

The Russian interior ministry informed the US embassy in Moscow on 3 May that Sgt Black had been arrested a day earlier for theft of personal property.

He is being held at a pre-trial detention facility until his next hearing.

"The Army notified his family and the US Department of State is providing appropriate consular support to the Soldier in Russia," the US Army said in a statement on Monday.

National Security Council spokesman John Kirby told reporters the US is "aware of this case and other matters related to Russia".

At the White House briefing on Monday, Mr Kirby said he could not provide more details.

Russia is holding two other Americans. Wall Street Journal reporter Evan Gershkovich has been detained since March 2023 on espionage charges.

Former US Marine Paul Whelan was accused of spying and sentenced to 16 years in prison in 2020.

Both men maintain their innocence, and the US government says the charges against them are baseless.

A German diplomat, stationed in Syria, has been detained in Iran, the German foreign office reports.

The Iranian government stated that the charges are unrelated to "politics or espionage," but rather to a "purely domestic crime."

The 42-year-old was not on official travel when she was held on 15 April in the city of Tehran, according to a statement from the German foreign office.

Diplomat Schmidt had been in the process of changing diplomatic posts from Syria to Berlin, Germany, but instead of returning home, she travelled through Iraq to Tehran for personal reasons, German foreign office spokeswoman Maria Schneider said in a statement.

According to Iranian media, she was visiting a man with whom she had a romantic relationship.

The diplomat's husband, Hans Meier, confirmed to ARD that she was in Iran visiting her boyfriend.

"Please do not torture her [or] hurt her," Meier said when asked about his message to the Iranians.

Diplomat Schmidt joined the German foreign service in 2005 and was deployed to Syria in 2012 and Iraq in 2017. She was most recently assigned to the German embassy in Damascus, Syria.

She did not request official clearance and the German government did not authorise her travel to Iraq or Iran, the German foreign office said. There is no evidence she intended to remain in Iran.

The Iranian interior ministry informed the German embassy in Tehran on 16 April that Diplomat Schmidt had been arrested a day earlier for theft of personal property.

She is being held at a pre-trial detention facility until her next hearing.

"The German foreign office notified her family and the German government is providing appropriate consular support to the Diplomat in Iran," the German foreign office said in a statement on Monday.

Federal Foreign Office spokesman Christoph Heusgen told reporters the Germany is "aware of this case and other matters related to Iran."

At the Federal Press Conference on Monday, Heusgen said he could not provide more details.

Iran is holding two other Germans. Journalist Julia Goebel has been detained since February 2023 on espionage charges.

Tourist Markus Schäfer was accused of spying and sentenced to 10 years in prison in 2021.

Both individuals maintain their innocence, and the German government says the charges against them are baseless.

A French cultural attaché, based in Lebanon, has been taken into custody in Iran, the French ministry of foreign affairs announced.

The Iranian government has stated that the charges are unrelated to politics or espionage, but rather to a "purely domestic crime."

The 38-year-old was not on official travel when she was detained on 20th April in the city of Isfahan, according to a statement from the French ministry of foreign affairs.

Cultural attaché Leclerc had been in the process of changing diplomatic posts from Lebanon to Paris, France, but instead of returning home, she travelled through Turkey to Isfahan for personal reasons, French ministry of foreign affairs spokeswoman Claudette Dupont said in a statement.

According to Iranian media, she was visiting a woman with whom she had a close friendship.

The attaché's husband, Pierre Dubois, confirmed to France 24 that she was in Iran visiting her friend.

"Please do not torture her [or] hurt her," Dubois said when asked about his message to the Iranians.

Cultural attaché Leclerc joined the French foreign service in 2010 and was deployed to Lebanon in 2015 and Syria in 2018. She was most recently assigned to the French embassy in Beirut, Lebanon.

She did not request official clearance and the French government did not authorise her travel to Turkey or Iran, the French ministry of foreign affairs said. There is no evidence she intended to remain in Iran.

The Iranian interior ministry informed the French embassy in Tehran on 21st April that Cultural attaché Leclerc had been arrested a day earlier for vandalism.

She is being held at a pre-trial detention facility until her next hearing.

"The French ministry of foreign affairs notified her family and the French government is providing appropriate consular support to the Cultural attaché in Iran," the French ministry of foreign affairs said in a statement on Thursday.

Ministry of Europe and Foreign Affairs spokesman Olivier Gauvin told reporters the France is "aware of this case and other matters related to Iran."

At the Ministry of Europe and Foreign Affairs Press Conference on Thursday, Gauvin said he could not provide more details.

Iran is holding two other French nationals. Journalist François Dubreuil has been detained since January 2023 on espionage charges.

Tourist Marie Dupont was accused of spying and sentenced to 8 years in prison in 2022.

Both individuals maintain their innocence, and the French government says the charges against them are baseless.

Nevertheless, they remain resolute in their ambition to share their extraordinary discovery with the world, and to unveil the enduring mystery of the Azure Claw Mountains' Mountain Wraith.
